{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2984724,"name":null,"username":"anon53289118","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/7ab992/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-03T01:23:01.320Z","cooked":"
github.com

GitHub - modelmat/frc-ctre-drop-in-replacement: Wrappers for CTRE's motor...

Wrappers for CTRE's motor controller API which creates WPILIB-compatible versions of common classes. - GitHub - modelmat/frc-ctre-drop-in-replacement: Wrappers for CTRE's motor controller A...

This is a small-ish library which provides three wrappers:

  • PhoenixMotorControllerGroup: A version of WPILib’s MotorController group that uses CAN device following functionality.
  • TalonEncoder: A replacement for frc::Encoder, which is not a subclass, but implements most of the usable methods. Should allow just the class names to be switched and everything to just work.
  • TalonEncoderSim: A replacement for frc::sim::EncoderSim, same as above.

For more details, see the README files in the github repo.

The repository is structured as modifications of WPILib’s State Space DifferentialDrive Simulation projects; viewing the commit history shows the specific changes done from the original example to demonstrate what exactly needs to be done to utilise them.

For Java, the classes are located in src/main/java/ctre_sims, and C++ in ctre-shims in the root of the repository.

This should make CTRE’s motor controller functionality easier to use, especially when encoders are involved, as existing WPILib examples and documentation should just “work”, and if not, the code demonstrates how to do the equivalent functions (e.g. encoder.GetDistance() => motor.GetSelectedSensorPosition() * m_distancePerPulse)

Since someone asked, by “sane units”, by default velocity is converted to counts / second instead of per 100ms, and you can utilise the encoder.SetDistancePerPulse in the same way you can with WPILib encoders to convert the units to the semantically valid ones.

Disclaimer: I have not tested this on an actual robot, only in simulation, but the code that this is based on was used by my team last season. The main issues I had during simulation testing were due to sensor/motor inversions, so if you have issues that’s probably the main item to check.

For C++, it would be cool to have overloads which worked with C++ units. It saves having to do conversions, both of types and of the actual values. It would be even cooler to have CTRE do this…

(For example, GetDistance and GetRate for the encoder class could have the drop-in replacements, but also have versions with the unit-specific parameter types).

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2022-01-03T02:08:16.642Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":189,"readers_count":188,"score":57.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":398614,"topic_slug":"introducing-drop-in-sane-units-ctre-motor-encoder-wrappers","display_username":"Allen Nuttle","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14283,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/introducing-drop-in-sane-units-ctre-motor-encoder-wrappers/398614/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2984732,"name":null,"username":"anon53289118","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/7ab992/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-03T02:55:47.859Z","cooked":"

Definitely would be nice for CTRE to do units (not even just unit classes, but the conversion factor from counts => distance), but they’ve got various blockers as to why they don’t.

As to why this doesn’t use units in C++, it was intended as a drop-in replacement for the WPILib classes, and those don’t currently support units, so if the classes required you to specify the base unit in a template like is done here then it breaks the other code. WPILib does seem to be moving towards unitted-classes where possible, but it seems to be a breaking change.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2022-01-03T02:55:47.859Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":166,"readers_count":165,"score":38.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":398614,"topic_slug":"introducing-drop-in-sane-units-ctre-motor-encoder-wrappers","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib/blob/f57c188f2e3d0e9cf0de80e2a1cbb76f10a3e8fa/wpimath/src/main/native/include/frc/controller/ElevatorFeedforward.h#L17-L26","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":14283,"username":"nuttle","name":"Allen Nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41441,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/introducing-drop-in-sane-units-ctre-motor-encoder-wrappers/398614/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2984778,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-03T14:09:01.211Z","cooked":"

To make things more concrete, if one has some class with double GetX() and SetX(double), it’s easy to just add units::angle::turns GetX() and SetX(units::angle::turns). Once this is done, any unit type that is convertible to turns may be passed. The compiler will figure out if the double or turns form of GetX() or SetX() is needed to match things up.

I see what your wrappers do, and that’s great! I didn’t want to sidetrack things. It’s more that it would be nice for the vendors to start moving to using C++ units, and wrapper classes are the place to do this unless/until they do so. Because of overloading, there’s a very painless migration path. I’m interested in knowing more about what’s blocking this. Of course, the template approach you linked is even better; this might be the cleanest way to go, especially for supporting both linear and angular units.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2022-01-03T14:09:32.518Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":89,"readers_count":88,"score":27.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":398614,"topic_slug":"introducing-drop-in-sane-units-ctre-motor-encoder-wrappers","display_username":"Allen Nuttle","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14283,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/introducing-drop-in-sane-units-ctre-motor-encoder-wrappers/398614/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2984793,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-03T15:08:11.304Z","cooked":"
nuttle:

if one has some class with double GetX() and SetX(double), it’s easy to just add units::angle::turns GetX() and SetX(units::angle::turns). Once this is done, any unit type that is convertible to turns may be passed. The compiler will figure out if the double or turns form of GetX() or SetX() is needed to match things up.

Unfortunately this is not the case for GetX() in your example. The compiler has no way to disambiguate calls based solely on return value, and C++ name mangling does not encode the return type. Thus trying to declare two GetX() functions with different return types will result in a compiler error. You have three choices: name the units one something different, add a dummy parameter so the parameters are different, or have just one function and change its return type (which is a breaking change).

Yep – overgeneralized the Set side of things without thinking! It would be good to add units though, still doesn’t seem like an issue if you go with non-breaking additions.
